objectives: Review course goals, objectives, and syllabus for both Semesters
Understand WHO you are: What are your interests? What are your likes? What is your personality profile?
Understand WHAT you are: Identify your academic and extra-curricular strengths
Identify objectives for future college study
content.overview:
Knowing yourself: Who are you and what are you equals knowing yourself. This lesson will help you to identify your personality, personal strengths and interests.

Knowing who and what you are will help you develop your high school plan for academics and extracurricular activities. You will develop your character profile, which will help you create a plan for what you might want to study in high school and college and help you choose the college/university that is the best fit for you.
content.title: Week One: Who and What Are You?

content.heading: A Student’s Journey: To College and Beyond
content.synopsis: Listen to the audio clip to learn a bit about the course and what you will be learning.

content.title: Class Syllabus
content.synopsis: Review the syllabus and take a quiz to check for understanding.

responses: To help the student have fun in the U.S
To help the student become an American
To help the student apply and adjust to a U.S. University
questions.title: What is the primary goal of A Student’s Journey?
When will you learn how to write a college application essay?
The assessments include:

content.title: U.S. Higher Education Glossary
content.synopsis: The following article provides a glossary of important terms used specifically for International students while researching U.S. higher education.

questions.title: According to the article, who is the best source to use for academic advice and guidance at a U.S. University?
According to the article, which type of Visa allows an international student to attend a U.S. University?
According to the article, letters of Recommendation are most often written by:

content.heading: Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator (MBTI)
content.synopsis: This video will help you to learn about yourself, your personality traits, and your interests. It will also assist you in selecting your “best fit” school.

content.heading: Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator (MBTI)
content.synopsis: Learn About the Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator (MBTI)
content.instructions: Learn about the Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator by clicking on the link below and watch the slideshow by clicking on “Next” until you complete all 46 slides. Once complete you will take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, personality questionnaires do not measure:
According to the article, it is important for me to know my personality profile when considering which colleges to apply for because:
responses: This can help me chose a college or major that is a good fit for my personality
It’s fun to learn about myself
Colleges will ask for my personality profile
Test scores are important to college applications

questions.title: According to the article, how many codes does the personality type codes have?

According to the article, the first letter of your personality type code describes where you use your favorite mental muscle. In the inner world of ______ and ______ or the outer world of ______ and ______:
responses: Actions and Words or Thoughts and Emotions
Thoughts and Actions or Emotions and Words
Thoughts and Emotions or Actions and Words

questions.title: According to the article, you have four mental muscles at your disposal, which you use to process information and make decisions. They are ______:
According to the article, Thinking and Feeling are mental muscles used for making decisions or judgments. Thinking ______/Feeling ______:
responses: Seeks to promote and uphold personal values/Seeks to understand and apply universal principles
Asks: “Is it true and valid?”/Asks: “Is it important to me?”

questions.title: According to the article, which of your preferred mental muscles do you use when dealing with people?
According to the article, sensing and intuition are ways of perceiving or creating information. Sensing ______/Intuition ______:
responses: Asks: “Is it true and valid?”/Asks: “Is it important to me?”

questions.title: According to the article, introverts tend to:
According to the article, extraverts tend to:

content.heading: Take the Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator (MBTI)
content.synopsis: Now that you've learned about Myers Briggs, it is your turn to take it yourself.
content.instructions:
Click on the following link and take the MBTI by following the instructions. You will submit the questionnaire and once you receive an email with the results you will fill out your journal. If you would like to take the MBTI in Chinese, click on the drop down and change the language to Chinese.

  • Step 1: Click URL Arrive here…
  • Step 2: Click Language Drop-down.
  • Step 3: Select “Chinese, Simplified”. Page refreshes as…
  • Step 4: Enter:
    • First Name
    • Last name
    • Gender
    • Email
    WARNING! DO NOT ENTER CHINESE CHARACTERS IN THE NAME FIELDS.
  • Step 5: Answer all 93 questions and press Done at the bottom of the page.
WARNING! DO NOT PRESS the Save and Complete Later Button.

content.heading: Reflections on Myers Briggs
instructionList: What did you learn about Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator?
What is your personality type?
What are the advantages and/or disadvantages of your personality type?
Please describe what you agree or disagree with from the findings.
How has it been helpful to know your personality and how the result can help you in choosing a college or major?

content.heading: The Interest Profile
content.instructions:
You will take an Interest Profiler. Register with CFNC by creating your own account. Click on the link below and follow the instructions. Once logged in, click on “Plan” and scroll down to “Plan for A Career” and click on “Learn About Yourself”.

Take the Interest Profiler by clicking on > Interest Profiler.

content.heading: The Career Profile
content.instructions:
Now take the Career Cluster Survey about your strengths and interests. Click on “Plan” and scroll down to “Plan for A Career” and click on “Learn About Yourself”. Take the Career Cluster Survey by clicking on > Career Cluster Survey.

Once complete, review your results and return to journal about your experience.

content.heading: Reflection on Interests and Strengths
instructionList: What did you learn from your Interest Profiler and Career Cluster Survey?
What are your top two interest areas and do you agree with the findings?
What careers best match your interests and do you agree with these career choices?
How can you take what you’ve learned and apply it to your High School and College experience?
Are there careers of interest to you other than those suggested to you by CFNC? If yes, what are they?

content.title: Knowing Yourself
content.synopsis: Knowing this information about yourself, you will now be able to use your high school years wisely by engaging in extracurricular activities of interest and will be able to use this information in future years when choosing a college.
takeaways: Who you are: Your personality type, your interests and strengths
What you are: Your academic and extracurricular strengths
What college major you might enjoy
Knowing who and what you are will help you in finding the college that is the best fit for you

objectives: Understand the differences between the U.S. and Chinese educational systems
content.overview: Now that you understand about your personality type, let’s explore the differences between the U.S. and Chinese educational systems and learn something about the “best fit” concept.
content.title: Week Two: U.S. vs Chinese Educational Systems and “Best Fit”

content.synopsis: Watch the documentary “Two Million Minutes.”

content.heading: The Generation That’s Remaking China
content.synopsis: In this video, Yang Lan, a Chinese journalist, businesswoman and entrepreneur offers her views on todays youth in China. She discusses how she believes todays generation is perceived by the outside world.
content.instruction: Watch the video to see Yang Lan’s Ted Global talk. You will then take a quiz to check for understanding, and a journal for reflection.

questions.title: According to the video, what percent of Blog users are under the age of 30?
According to the video, college graduates sharing limited living spaces in urban areas call themselves _______?

content.heading: Reflection on Interests and Strengths
instructionList: Reflect about your life in the future.
Where do you think you will be in ten years?
Where will you live?
What type of job do you think you will have?
Will you be married?
How many jobs do you think you will have had?

content.synopsis: Watch the video to learn a bit about U.S. vs. Chinese Educational Systems.

content.heading: Reflection on Interests and Strengths
instructionList: Name three similarities and three differences between the Chinese and American educational systems.
Compare and contrast the ways in which Chinese and American students are assessed in school. For example how are tests, homework, and projects evaluated in both countries?
How are “extracurricular” activities the same in China as they are in the U.S.? How are they different?
Compare and contrast how Chinese and American students spend time outside of school.
Generally, what is the average class size in an American high school? How might this impact the way in which American students learn as compared to the way in which Chinese students learn?
List three strengths of the Chinese educational system and three strengths of the American educational system.

content.heading: Synopsis of the U.S. School System
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, which of the following is considered to be an extracurricular activity?
According to the article, public schools in the U.S. focus on a(n) ________________:

content.heading: Synopsis of the Chinese School System
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, how do students gain admission to colleges/universities in China?
responses: The students submit applications to only their favorite colleges
The students attend the same college as their parents
The colleges use a lottery system
The students are accepted according to their test results

questions.title: According to the article, at the end of every school year, Chinese high school students are tested for advancement to the next grade. If they are unable to pass the test, they are often left unable to finish their education.

content.title: A Student's Journey Volume 1
content.synopsis: Xin Xin learns about the U.S. university system and makes some critical decisions.
content.instructions: As you proceed through the comic, select the option that best fits the situation.

content.heading: Teaching and Teaching Strategies in the U.S. and in China
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, what is the main focus of teachers in the U.S. and in China?
responses: In the U.S. they focus on homework and in China they focus on testing
In the U.S. they focus on the individual and in China they focus on the group
In the U.S. they focus on elementary school and in China they focus on college

questions.title: According to the article, greater parental involvement in a child's education can foster more positive attitudes toward school, can improve homework habits, increase academic success and can reduce dropout rates.

content.heading: Comparison of Tracking Systems and High Stakes Testing
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, what is the main difference between the tracking systems and high stakes tests used in China and in the U.S.?
responses: They are used in the U.S. to select the best students and in China they are used to promote students
Both countries use different systems and tests
In the U.S. they are used to separate students into groups according to their ability level and in China they are used to measure learning
There is no difference in how they are used

questions.title: According to the article, high stakes tests used in the U.S. can achieve the following outcomes:

content.heading: Parental Involvement
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: Parental involvement is a critical component to a child's educational experience. What is the main difference between parents of U.S. and Chinese students?
responses: The teachers are equally involved in both countries

questions.title: Which of the following is NOT true?
responses: Chinese teachers and parents expect that all students have the ability to succeed in all subjects
A Chinese student will stay after class and work with the teacher one-on-one if he/she needs additional help
In the U.S., education focuses on the group more than an individual student
Students in Chinese schools perceive their classroom environments to be competitive and teacher-controlled

content.heading: Math and Reading Scores
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, the Stedman study shows:
responses: Chinese students achieve the best reading scores in the world
U.S. students show potential to win the next International Mathematics and Science Study
U.S. students often score high on science tests
U.S. students need to practice their math

questions.title: According to the article, U.S. and Chinese students standout in which of the following areas?
responses: U.S.: Reading and Science/China: Math and Science
They stand out in the same areas

content.heading: Strengths and Weaknesses of Both Systems
content.instructions: Click on the link, read the article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, which of the following is a benefit of the Chinese educational system?
responses: Chinese teachers are not given more respect than U.S. teachers
Chinese schools do not have a hard work ethic, resulting in student failure
Chinese schools segregate high achieving students from lower achieving students through tracking levels
Chinese schools help students pass high stakes tests, however, those who fail often drop out

questions.title: According to the article, what are some of the strengths of the Chinese educational system in comparison to the U.S. system?
responses: Better pay for teachers, more school activities, fewer tests
Longer school day, larger schools, more class choices
More respect for teachers, strong work ethic, belief in student potential
Better textbooks, holidays for teachers, more student effort

content.heading: “Best Fit”
content.synopsis: Now let’s learn a bit about how to select colleges that will be the “best fit” for you!

questions.title: According to the video, what does “Best Fit” mean in the video?
responses: The college/university that is the “best fit” for you
The clothes that “best fits” your personality

questions.title: According to the video, what should you consider when developing your school list?
responses: If the school offers a strong program in a major that interests you
If the school offers financial aid

content.title: Picking the Right School
content.synopsis: Read the following article and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, when gathering information, what is the best way to find out about a specific college/university?
responses: Contact the school directly or visit their website

questions.title: According to the article, what are some of the aspects you should consider when choosing the ‘right’ college/university?
responses: You prefer to live at home or on campus
Tuition, financial aid and scholarships available
You prefer to attend a large university or a smaller private college

questions.title: According to the article, what is the best reason to choose one school over another?
responses: Your friends will be going there
The school offers a strong program in a major which interests you
The “best” reason comes down to what’s most important to you

content.heading: Best Fit
content.synopsis: Watch this video to see what students have to say!

content.heading: Best Fit
content.synopsis: Watch this video to see what students have to say!

content.heading: Finding the Best School for You.
instructionList: Write a brief explanation of what you think “best fit” school means to you.
What types of things do you think you should consider as you develop your school lists? (Remember what you learned about yourself in Week One)
What do you think schools consider when selecting you for admission?
What else should you consider besides just the name or ranking of a college/university?
You will reflect back on this entry at the end of the first semester.

content.title: Finding the Best School for You
content.synopsis: You now have a better understanding of the U.S. educational system to better transition to a U.S. college/university. Add to your understanding of who you are by better understanding the educational system of China. Use the knowledge about yourself and the educational system from which you came to identity schools that would be the best fit for you.
takeaways: The differences between U.S. and Chinese educational systems
Information about U.S. educational system to help you transition to a U.S. college/university
Important criteria for choosing a college/university that will be a good fit for you
Differences between how Chinese and U.S. students spend time outside of school

content.title: Week Three: Reality of College Admissions in the U.S.
content.overview: Now that you have learned some interesting things about your personality, strengths and interests and how that relates to choosing a college/university. Let’s take a bit of time to review the “best fit” concept and then explore the reality of the college admissions landscape in the United States.
objectives: Review the concepts of “fit” vs. name or ranking
Assess your own chances of admission at a variety of colleges
Research application numbers and acceptance rates for international students as well as other important admissions application data
Understand the current college admissions landscape for elite schools in the U.S.

content.heading: Reviewing Best Fit School
content.synopsis: Review the concept of “Best Fit” by choosing three videos provided from the two links below. Choose videos in which people talk about their experience in choosing a college/university which is a good fit for them. After you watch the three videos you chose, you will then journal about things to consider while looking for a “best fit” school. There are many videos on the websites which may be of interest to you, so you might want to spend even more time exploring videos of interest.
content.instruction: Click on the links and find two videos that help you understand how to find a university or college that is a good fit for you.

content.heading: Reviewing Best Fit School
instructionList: Write a brief explanation of what you think “best fit” school means to you.
Describe what types of issues you are worried about as you begin your college planning.  For example, is there pressure to get into a “top” school?
Determine if you have concerns about finding the right major and fitting in with your new friends.
If you do have some concerns, what can you do to make yourself more educated about these concerns and less anxious?
What types of things do you think you should consider as you develop your School List?

content.heading: The Reality of College Admissions
content.synopsis: Let’s start learning about different perspectives regarding the reality of College Admissions in the U.S. by watching a short video.

content.title: Best, Brightest and Rejected
content.synopsis:
Despite high grades, elite colleges turn away as much as 95% of their applicants.

Read the following article to get a better view of this perspective. A quiz will be provided afterwards to check your understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, prestigious schools have had a(n) ______ amount of college applications and a(n) ______ percentage of admission rate.
Choose the cause(s) for the new low college acceptance rate among elite universities:
responses: Students are sending out more college applications than ever AND Elite colleges are offering 20 percent less admission seats than a generation ago
College outreach programs nowadays advertise increasingly aggressive to prospective students

College applications are becoming more similar and uniform which makes the attempt to apply for multiple schools easier AND Elite colleges are offering 20 percent less admission seats than a generation ago
Students are sending out more college applications than ever AND College applications are becoming more similar and uniform which makes the attempt to apply for multiple schools easier

questions.title: According to the article, which of the following statements are false?
responses: Most of the students these elite colleges turn down are indistinguishable from those who get in
20% more students are applying to 7 or more colleges in 2011 compared to the percentage of the applicant pool in 1990
Every school seems accessible to most college applicants because they have access to so much information online
Several universities had admission rates this year that were more than half of those from a decade ago

content.heading: The Reality of College Admissions
content.synopsis: There are many perspectives about the college admissions process and the probability of getting into a school of your choice. Let’s listen to John Katzman as he offers his unique perspective of the U.S. College Admissions landscape.
content.instruction: Click on the link below, watch the video and take a quiz to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the video, what is the reason that getting into an elite college/university is easier than it used to be?
responses: Top universities are offering a higher rate of added seats compared to the lower rate of increased number of applicants
State schools are getting more popular which leaves fewer college applicants to apply for elite schools
High school graduates are better educated and can easily go into any schools they want
Elite schools are trying to raise their ranking by increasing admission rate

questions.title: According to the video, how are the admissions rates calculated?
responses: Admissions rates equal the total number of students admitted minus the total number of applications
Admissions rates equal the total number of students admitted times the total number of applications
Admissions rates equal the total number of students admitted divided by the total number of applications
Admissions rates equal the total number of students admitted

questions.title: According to the video, which of the following is NOT suggested from the video to increase one’s chance to get into a great school?
responses: An applicant should pick from 10 great schools that he/she is indifferent
An applicant should use early options
An applicant should harden his/her heart, ignore bad advice, and be his/her best self
An applicant should simply apply to as many school as he/she can

content.title: For Students, a Waiting List Is a Scant Hope
content.synopsis: Let’s read an article from the perspective of a student on the waiting list.

questions.title: According to the article, longer waiting lists are a result of _____________________.
responses: Being overwhelmed by the volume of admissions, officials simply ran out of time
The admissions process is a complicated one
Admissions officials are hedging their bets by waiting to see how many of the students selected say yes

questions.title: According to the article, students are ranked on the waiting list according to _________________.
responses: The strength of their college essay
What the admissions office perceives as deficiencies in the next freshman class

content.title: College Admissions Rates: An Imperfect Metric
content.synopsis:
In this article, we will explore the college admissions rates for the class of 2018. As you will see, while imperfect, this metric is closely watched.

Read the article for more information. Afterward, you will take a quiz to test your understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, admissions rates don’t really convey the chances for any one applicant. True or False:
According to the article, Duke University’s admissions rate for the class of 2018 is _________?
According to the article, Harvard’s admissions rate for the class of 2018 is ________?
According to the article, the total number of applications rise and fall based on which of the following?
responses: The number of applicants accepted through early decision
If the college requires a supplemental essay
If the college counts anyone who starts the process and pays a fee or if they count applications in some other way

content.title: Admissions Data
content.synopsis:
Let’s review some admissions data to understand the acceptance rates at some schools which might be of interest to you.

Read the article for more information. Afterward, you will take a quiz to test your understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, in 2009, which school encouraged students to submit a short video as a part of the undergraduate application process?
According to the article, which school admits 100% of their applicants?
According to the article, in 2012, which school was the most selective public university in the U.S.?

content.heading: Admissions Rates for International Students
content.instructionListHeader: Follow these step-by-step directions on how to search college acceptance rates for international students and prepare for your next journal entry.
instructionsList:
Follow these step-by-step directions on how to search college acceptance rates for international students and prepare for your next journal entry.

  • choose three colleges/universities to which you are interested in applying/li>
  • The name of the school you choose will be your keyword to search on the internet
  • Please check the site you are going to click on, and make sure it is not an advertisement(Hint: does the address end in .edu?)
  • Where on the home page can you find general information about the school?
  • Where on the home page can you find information on how to apply to the school?
  • Where on the home page can you find information related to international students?

Click on the school website, and explore:

  • Click on “Admissions” on the top left corner
  • Click on “Undergraduate Admissions”
  • Click on “Applying”
  • Click on” Application Overview”
  • Scroll down to the middle of the page and you will see “View the class of 2018 profile”
  • Click on “View the class of 2018 profile”
  • Scroll down the page,

You will find the information such as:

  • Acceptance/Enrollment Summary/Testing/Diversity/Gender
  • Type of Secondary School
  • Geographic Distribution
  • Current Student Profile
  • Important Dates
Click on the school website, and explore:

If you can’t find the answers by exploring the school web page, is there any other method you can use to find out the information you need? (Hint: Is there a phone number or email address of someone you could contact?)

content.heading: Reviewing Best Fit School
content.instructions: Use the information from the previous activity to answer the following questions.
instructionList: Is the admission rate the same for international students and American students at American universities?
From what countries are international students applying to U.S. colleges and universities?
What are the top three countries which are sending students to the U.S. to study?
What are the top three majors for undergraduate international students?
Generally, are the admission requirements for international students different from the admission requirements for American students?

If you can’t find the answers by exploring the school web page, is there any other method you can use to find out the information you need? (Hint: Is there a phone number or email address of someone you could contact?)

content.heading: Interview with an Admissions Counselor
content.synopsis:
Let’s listen to an interview with Anne Sjostrom, Associate Director, Undergraduate Admissions at Duke University as she talks about the liberal arts program and choosing majors, undergraduate research support, and combining studies and sports/athletics at Duke University.

Citation: mycollegeguide.org

content.heading: Interview with an Admissions Counselor Pt. 2
content.synopsis: Let’s listen to an interview with Maxine Mendoza, an Admissions Officer at UPenn. She gives advice about applying to college and she discusses opportunities for international students, such as research opportunities for undergraduate students and study abroad programs at the University of Pennsylvania.

content.heading: Interview with an Admissions Counselor Pt. 3
content.synopsis: Listen to Lauren Sutton, Associate Director of Admissions for Rhodes College in Memphis Tennessee share her thoughts on International Admissions.

content.instruction: You will enter the DISCUSSION FORUM as previously instructed and write your response to the following discussion prompts:
instructionList: The most important thing I learned about admissions rates for international students is:

What are the most important aspects when choosing a college/university which will be a good fit for you?  For example, is the ranking or “name” of the college/university your guiding principle, or are you more interested in finding a college/university which offers the strongest program in your area of interest?  Is cost an issue when putting a college on your list?  Will it make a difference to you if your friends are applying to some of the schools on your list?  You will begin placing schools on your college/university list at the end of this lesson and continue adjusting your list as you learn more in the following lessons.
What do you think schools consider when selecting you for admission?
Which perspective about admissions rates of colleges/universities do you agree with the most?

content.heading: Selective Vs. Highly Selective
content.instructions:
You have learned a lot in this lesson about the reality of admissions rates in U.S. colleges/universities. Assess your own chances of admission at a variety of colleges.

Finally, let’s start creating your School List!

Use your understanding of yourself, the “best fit” concept, and the reality of the U.S. college admissions, please indicate your top FIVE colleges/universities to which you are most interested in applying. You will continue to refine this list as you learn more in the following lessons.

content.title: Admissions and Selectivity
content.synopsis: After this lesson, you now have a firm understanding of the reality of admissions in U.S. colleges and universities.
takeaways: The application numbers and acceptance rates specific to international students
Information about admissions rates for top colleges and universities
The admissions landscape in the U.S.
You have started your School List!

content.title: Week Four: Getting to Know the Regions of the U.S.
content.overview: You have learned a bit about yourself (Week One), the differences between U.S. and Chinese educational systems and the “best fit” concept (Weeks Two & Three), and the reality of U.S. college admissions (Week Three). Now in Week Four you will explore the different regions in the U.S. and understand the type of culture, climate and location of the colleges and universities on your list.
objectives: Explore the different geographic regions in the U.S. (Northeast, South, Midwest, and West)
Locate major U.S. cities and urban centers
Learn about the different cultures of the various parts of the U.S., e.g. weather, food, language, customs, activities
Continue to increase the number of colleges and universities on your School List

content.heading: Getting to Know the Regions of the U.S.
content.synopsis: It is important to know where colleges/universities are located in the U.S. as you develop your School List. Some students are surprised by the climate or culture of a location and we want you to choose colleges/universities in locations where you will be comfortable and happy.

content.heading: Getting to Know the Geography and Culture of the U.S.
content.synopsis:
Let’s learn a bit about the geography of the U.S. by playing this fun game to learn the names of the various states and where they are located. After you learn the names and location of the states, click on the U. S. regions link to learn about the culture and history of each region. In this game, there are eight regions.  It explains how the geography, politics and history of each region can be quite different.

Now that you have learned about how to find your “best fit” school and how the admissions process works in the U.S., it’s time to start looking for a school that will be the best fit for you!

One of the first steps in finding your best fit school is deciding where you will be most happy. The U.S. is a large country with several different regions. Next, you will have the opportunity to explore the geography of the U.S.
content.instructions:
Click on the links and practice learning the names and location of the different states, regions and lakes of the U.S. Practice until you master it.

Happy exploring!

content.heading: Exploring the Unitied States
content.instructions: Please write one interesting fact from each of the regions in the U.S. and why that would cause you to (a) want to , or (b) NOT want to live in that region.

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: You will read the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding. Samuel Arbesman is an applied mathematician and network scientist. He is a senior scholar at the Kauffman Foundation and a fellow at the Institute for Quantitative Social Science at Harvard University. His writing has appeared in The New York Times, The Atlantic, Wired, New Scientist, and The Boston Globe.

questions.title: According to the article, which one of these is not an administrative border?
According to the article, which of these is not an organic border?

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: Continue reading the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding.

questions.title: What was the purpose of the research conducted by the writer of the article?
responses: To find out where people move
To find out how we create cultural and social borders
To find out a region’s favorite sports team
To find out how we speak

questions.title: What did the writer discover in his research?
responses: That sometimes political boundaries and social boundaries do not coincide
That political boundaries are more important than social boundaries
That social boundaries are more important than political boundaries
That there is no difference between political and social boundaries

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: Continue reading the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, what kind of data was collected for the study?
According to the article, what was concluded after analyzing the data?
responses: That when people move, they don’t speak to people they used to know
That when people move, they continue speaking to people they used to know
That people don’t move far away from their home state
That people don’t speak to people in other states

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: Continue reading the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding.

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: Continue reading the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding.

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: Continue reading the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding.

questions.title: According to the article, connections were found between where we live and:
responses: Shopping for soft drinks, playing baseball, voting Democrat
Words for soft drinks, voting, sports
Drinking Coke, being a Yankees fan, being a Republican
They did not find any other connections

questions.title: According to the article, where are the natural borders located?
responses: New England, New Jersey, Texas, and California.
New York, New England, and New Jersey.
They did not find any natural borders.

content.title: The Invisible Borders That Define American Culture
content.synopsis: Finish reading the article written by Samuel Arbesman in small portions and answer questions to check for understanding.

questions.title: What does the author conclude from his research?
responses: That our cultural similarities influence how we behave, how we communicate, and who we communicate with
That our cultural similarities don’t matter when we live in a complex society
That we need to learn more about other cultures
That we don’t communicate well with other cultures

content.heading: U.S. Geography Internet Scavenger Hunt
content.instuctionsHeader: Let’s explore! Using the keywords and guiding questions, you will learn more details about each region of the U.S. After learning specifics about each region or state of interest to you within a region, you will answer the following questions in your journal:
instructionsList: Describe which U.S. region you found most interesting.
In which region would you prefer to live? Why?
What is the climate of each region?
What kind of climate is most desirable to you?
How easy is it to get to the region you choose from China? and from each state?
What are the cultural nuances to this region?

content.heading: Reviewing Best Fit School
content.instructions: Use materials from your internet scavenger hunt to answer the following.
instructionList: Describe which U.S. region you found most interesting.
In which region would you prefer to live? Why?
What is the climate of each region?
What kind of climate is most desirable to you?
How easy is it to get to the region you choose from China? and from each state?
What are the cultural nuances to this region?

content.heading: Getting to Know the U.S. and Different U.S. Colleges and Universities
content.synopsis: Let’s learn more about building your School List by watching the video.

content.heading: Updating Your College List
content.instructions: Now that you know more about the culture, climate and geography and have a bit more information about building your School List, take some time to update your list.
instructionList: Are there any schools you want to remove from your School List because the location doesn’t appeal to you?
What are some great schools within your favorite region that you will add to your School List?
You will continue adding to this list in the following weeks.

content.title: Exploring the United States
content.synopsis: In this lesson, you learned about the culture, climate, and geographical regions of the U.S. Having a good understanding of this information will help you to better choose colleges and universities in locations that are a good fit for you.
takeaways: The different geographic regions in the U.S. (Northeast, South, Midwest, and West) and familiarized yourself with the different cultures of the various parts of the U.S., e.g. weather, food, language, customs, activities
To increase your vocabulary by defining several important terms
How to locate major U.S. cities and urban centers
